div.p: Prometheus Unbound Act Two
MS Shelley e. 1,2,3
<SCENE 1> Act 2. Scene Morning--{a} «ins»lovely«/ins» {V}ale in the Indian Caucasus--. Asia alone
{SD} Asia.
From all the blasts of Heaven thou hast descended--
Yes like a spirit, like a thought which makes
Unwonted tears throng to the horny eyes
And beatings haunt the desolated heart
Which should have learnt repose--thou hast descended
Cradled in tempests thou dost wake o Spring
O child of many winds. . As suddenly
Thou comest as the memory of a dream
Which now is sad because it hath been sweet;
Like genius or like joy which riseth up
As from the Earth clothing with golden clouds
The desart of our life. . . .
This is the season this the day the hour,
At sunrise thou shouldst come sweet sister mine. . .
Too long<del>-</del>desired too long delaying, come . . .
How like death-worms the wingless moments crawl!
The point of one white star is quivering still
Deep in the orange light of widening morn
Beyond the purple mountains; through a chasm
Of wind-divided mist the darker lake
Reflects it--now it wanes--it gleams again
As the waves fade, & as the burning threads
Of woven cloud unravel in pale air. . . .
Tis lost! & through yon peak of cloudlike snow
The roseate sunrise quivers--hear I not
The eolian music of her seagreen plumes
Winnowing the crimson dawn? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Panthea enters
I feel, I see
Those eyes which burn thro smiles that fade in tears
Like stars half quenched in mists of silver dew--
Beloved & most beautiful, who wearest
The shadow of that soul by which I live
How late thou art; the sphered {S}un had climbed
The sea, my heart was sick with hope, before
The printless air felt thy belated plumes. {SB}
{SD} Panthea
Pardon, {g}reat Sister! but my wings were faint
With the delight of a remembered dream
As are the noontide plumes of summer winds
Satiate with sweet flowers. I was wont to sleep
Peacefully, and awake refreshed & calm
Before the sacred Titan's fall, and thine
Unhappy love, had made through use & pity
Both love & woe familiar to my heart
As they had grown to yours . . . erewhile I slept
Under the glaucous caverns of old Ocean
Within dim bowers of green & purple moss;
Our young Ione's soft & milky arms
Locked then as now behind my dark moist hair
While my shut eyes & cheek were pressed within
The folded depth of her life-breathing bosom . . .
But not as now since I am made the wind
Which fails beneath the music that I bear
Of thy most wordless converse; since dissolved
Into the sense with which love talks, my rest
Was troubled & yet sweet--my waking hours
Too full of care & pain. {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
Lift up thine eyes
And let me read thy dream-- {SB} {HL}
{SD} Panthea
As I have said
With our sea-sister at his feet I slept
The mountain-mists condensing at our voice
Under the moon, had spread their snowy flakes
From the keen ice sh{ei}lding our linked sleep{.} . . .
Then two dreams came. One I remember not.
But in the other, his pale, wound-worn limbs
Fell from Prometheus, & the azure night
Grew radiant with the glory of that form
Which lives unchanged within, & his voice fell
Like music which makes dizzy the dim brain
Faint with intoxication of keen joy:
{'}Sister of her whose footsteps pave the world
With loveliness--more fair than aught but her
Whose shadow thou art--lift thine eyes on me!
I lifted them--the overpowering light
Of that immortal shape was shadowed oer
By love; which, from his soft & flowing limbs
And passion-parted lips, & keen faint eyes
Steam'd forth like vaporous fire; an atmosphere
Which wrapt me in its all-dissolving power
As the warm ether of the morning sun
Wraps ere it drinks some cloud of wandering dew.
I saw not--heard not--moved not--only felt
His presence flow & mingle thro my blood
Till it became his life & his grew mine
And I was thus absorbed--until it past
And like the vapours when the sun sinks down
Gathering again in drops upon the pines
And tremulous as they, in the deep night
My being was condensed, & as the rays
Of thought were slowly gathered, I could hear
His voice, whose accents lingered as they died
Like footsteps of far melody. . . . thy name,
Among the many sounds alone I heard
Of what might be articulate; though still
I listened through the night when sound was none.
Ione wakened then, & said to me
"Canst thou divine what troubles me to night
"I always knew what I desired before
"Nor ever found delight to wish in vain
"But now I cannot tell thee what I seek
"I know not--something sweet since it is sweet
"Even to desire--it is thy sport false {S}ister!
"Thou hast discovered <del>«und»some«/und»</del> inchantment old
"Whose spells have stolen my spirit as I slept
"And mingled it with thine;--for when just now
"We kissed, I felt within thy parted lips
The sweet air that sustained me, & the warmth
"Of the life-blood for loss of which I faint
Quivered between our intertwining arms"
I answered not, for the Eastern star grew pale
But fled to thee {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
Thou speakest, but thy words
Are as the air. I feel them not. . . . oh lift
Thine eyes that I may read his written soul. {SB}
{SD} Panthea
I lift them, though they droop beneath the load
Of that they would express--what canst thou see
But thine own fairest shadow imaged there {SB}
{SD} Asia
Thine eyes are like the deep blue boundless Heaven
Contracted to two circles underneath
Their long fine lashes--dark, far, measureless,--
Orb within orb, & line through line inwoven-- {SB}
{SD} Panthea
Why lookest thou as if a spirit past? {SB}
{SD} Asia
There is a change, beyond their inmost depth
I see a shade--a shape--'tis He, arrayed
In the soft light of his own smiles which spread
Like radiance from the cloud-surrounded moon
Prometheus it is {?thou}--depart not yet
Say not those smiles that we shall meet again
Within that bright Pavilion which th{e}r beams
Shall build oer the waste world? the dream is told
What shape is that between us? its rude hair
Roughens the wind that lifts it, its regard
Is wild & quick, yet 'tis a thing of air
For through its grey robe gleams the golden dew
Whose stars the noon has quenched not. {SB} {HL}
{SD} Dream
Follow, follow! {SB}
{SD} Panthea
It is mine other dream-- {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
It disappears. {SB}
{SD} Panthea
It passes now into my mind. methought
As we sate here the flower-infolding buds
Burst on yon lightning-blasted almond-tree
When swift, from the white Scythian wilderness,
A wind swept forth wrinkling the Earth with frost . . .
I looked, & all the blossoms were blown down
But on each leaf was stamped--as the blue bells
Of Hyacinth tell Apollos written grief--
«und»O, follow, follow!«/und» {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
As you speak your words
Fill, pause by pause mine own forgotten sleep
With shapes . . . methought among these lawns together
We wandered, underneath the young grey dawn
And multitudes of dense white fleecy clouds
Were wandering in thick flocks along the mountains
Shepherded by the slow unwilling wind{s};
And the white dew on the new-bladed grass
Just piercing the dark earth, hung silently--
And there was more which I remember not;
But, on the shadows of the moving clouds
Athwart the purple mountain slope was written
«und»Follow, o follow«/und» as they vanished by,
And on each herb from which Heaven's dew had fallen
The like was stamped as with a withering fire
A wind arose among the pines--it shook
The clinging music from their boughs, & then
Low sweet faint sounds like the farewell of ghosts
Were heard--«und»oh, follow, follow, follow me«/und»
And then I said Panthea look on me
But in the depth of those beloved eyes
Still I saw, «und»follow, follow. «/und» {SB} {HL}
{SD} Echo
Follow, follow! {SB}
{SD} Panthea
The crags this clear spring morning mock our voices
As they were spirit-tongued {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
It is some being
Around the crags--what fine clear sounds--o list {SB}
{SD} Echoes unseen
Echoes we--listen
We cannot stay
As dew-stars glisten
Then fade away{--}
Child of Ocean! {SB}
{SD} Asia
Hark spirits speak! the liquid responses
Of thier aerial tongues yet sound-- {SB} {HL}
{SD} Panthea
I hear. {SB}
{SD} Echoes
O follow follow
As our voice recedeth
Thro the caverns hollow
Where the forest spreadeth
{SD} More distant
O follow follow
Throughthe caverns hollow
As the song floats, thou pursue
Where the wild-bee never flew
Through the noontide darkness deep
By the odour breathing sleep
Of faint night{-}flowers, & the waves
At the fountain-lighted caves
While our music wild & sweet
Mocks thy gently-falling feet
Child of Ocean! {SB}
{SD} Asia
Shall we pursue the sound{?--} it grows more faint
And distant {SB} {HL}
{SD} Panthea
list--the strain floats nearer now {SB}
{SD} Echo
In the world unknown
Sleeps a voice unspoken
By thy step alone
Can its rest be broken
Child of Ocean {SB}
{SD} Asia
How the notes sink upon the ebbing wind {SB}
{SD} Echo
O follow follow
Thro the caverns hollow
As the song floats, thou pursue
By the wood land noontide dew
By the forests lakes & fountains
Thro the many-folded mountains
To the rents & gulphs & chasms
Where the Earth reposed from spasms
On the day when He & thou
Parted--to conmingle now
Child of Ocean {SB}
{SD} Asia
Come sweet Panthea--link thine hand in mine
And follow, ere the voices fade away {SB}
<SCENE 2> Scene 2. A forest intermingled With rocks & caverns. Asia & Panthea pass into it--2 young fawns are sitting on a rock listening
{SD} Semi-Chorus of Spirits--1
The path through which that lovely twain
Have past{,--} by cedar, pine & yew
And each dark tree that ever grew
Is curtained out from Heaven's wide blue
Nor sun nor moon nor wind nor rain
Can pierce its interwoven bowers;
Nor aught save {?where} some cloud of dew
Drifted along the earth-creeping breeze
Between the trunks of the hoar trees
Hangs each a pearl in the pale flowers
Of the green laurel, blown anew;
And bends & then fades silently
One frail & fair anemone:
Or {?where} some star of many a one
That climb & wander through steep Night
Has found the cleft thro which alone
Beams fall from high those depths upon,
Ere it is borne away, away,
By the swift Heavens that cannot stay--
It scatters drops of golden light
Like lines of rain that ne'er unite:
And the gloom divine is all around
And underneath is the mossy ground {SB}
{SD} Semichorus 2.
There the voluptuous nightingales
Are awake through all the broad noonday
When one with bliss or sadness fails
<del>A</del>nAnd through the windless ivy-boughs
Sick with sweet love, droops dying away
On its mates music-panting bosom--
Another from the swinging blossom
Watching to catch the languid close
Of the last strain, then lifts on high
The wings of the weak melody
Till some new {stream} of feeling bear
? The song{,} & all the woods are mute;
When there is heard thro' the dim air
The rush of wings, & rising there
Like many a lake-surrounded flute
Sounds overflow the listeners brain
So sweet, that joy is almost pain. {SB}
{SD} Semichorus 1.
There those inchanted eddies play
Of echoes music-tongued, which draw
By Demogorgons mighty law
With melting rapture or deep awe
All spirits on that secret way,
As inland boats are driven to Ocean
Down streams made strong with mountain-thaw;
And first there comes a gentle sound
To those in talk or slumber bound
And wakes the destined--soft emotion
Attracts, impels them: those who saw
Say from the breathing Earth behind
There steams a plume-uplifting wind
Which drives them on their path, while they
Believe their own swift wings & feet
The sweet desire{s} within obey
And so they float upon their way
Until still sweet but loud & strong
The storm of sound is driven along
Sucked up & hurrying--as they fleet
Behind its gathering billows meet
And to the fatal mountain bear
Like clouds amid the yielding air {SB}
{SD} enter Fauns 1st Faun
Canst thou imagine where those spirits live
Which make such delicate music in the woods?
We haunt within the least frequented caves
And closest coverts, & we know these wilds,
Yet never meet them though we hear them oft,
Where may they hide themselves? {SB} {HL}
{SD} 2d Faun
'Tis hard to tell--
I have heard those more skilled in spirits say
The bubbles which the enchantment of the sun
Sucks from the pale faint water-flowers, that pave
The oozy bottom of clear lakes & pools
Are the pavilions where such dwell, & float
Under the green & golden atmosphere
Which {the} noon«ins»tide«/ins» kindles through the woven leaves
And when these burst, & the thin fiery air
shining {homes} The which they breathed within those lucid homes{,} lucent domes
Ascends to flow like meteors through the night{--}
They ride on & & They rein their headlong speed, & glide in fire
And bow thier burning crests
Under the waters of the Earth again {SB}
{SD} 1st
If such live thus, have others other lives
Under pink blossoms or within the bells
Of meadow flowers, or folded violets deep
Or on thier dying odours, when they die
Or in the sunlight of the sphered dew? {SB}
{SD} 2d
Aye, many more{,} which we may well divine
But should we {try} to speak, noontide wd come{,}
And thwart Silenus find his goats undrawn
And grudge to sing those wise & lovely songs/Our solitary solitary twilights, & which charm/To silence the unenvying nightingales . .
Of fate & chance & God, & Chaos old{;}
And love, & the chained Titans woful doom
And how he shall be loosed, & make the Earth
One brotherhood--delighful strains which cheer
{SB}
<SCENE 3> Scene 3. A pinnacle of rock among Mountains--Asia & Panthea
{SD} Panthea
Hither the sound has borne us--to the realm
Of Demogorgon, & the mighty portal
Like a Volcano's meteor-breathing chasm
Whence the oracular vapour is breathed up
Which lonely men drink wandering in their youth
And call truth, virtue, love, genius or joy
That maddening wine of life, whose dregs they drain
To deep intoxication, & uplift
Like Mænads who cry loud Evoe! Evoe!
The voice which is contagion to the world. {SB}
{SD} Asia
Fit throne for such a power! Magnificent{:}
How glorious art thou Earth! & if thou beest
The shadow of some Spirit lovelier still
Though evil stain its work and it should be
Like its creation, weak yet beautiful
I could fall down & worship that & thee--
Even now my heart adoreth--Wonderful!
Look Sister--ere the vapour dim thy brain;
Beneath is a wide plain of billowy mist
As a lake, paving in the morning sky,
With azure waves which burst in silver light
Some Indian vale . . . behold it, rolling on
Under the curdling winds, & islanding
The peak whereon we stand--midway, around
Encinctured by the dark & blooming forests
Dim twilight lawns & stream-illumed caves
And wind-inchanted shapes of wandering mist
And far on high the keen sky-cleaving mountains
From icy spires of sunlike radiance fling
The dawn, as lifted Oceans dazzling spray
From some Atlantic islet scattered up
Spangles the wind with lamp-like water drops
The vale is girdled with their walls--a howl
Of cataracts from their thaw-cloven ravines
Satiates the listening wind, continuous, vast,
Awful as silence--hark! the rushing snow
The sun-awakened avalanche, whose mass
Thrice sifted by the storm had gathered there
Flake after flake: in Heaven-defying minds
As thought by thought is piled, till some great truth
Is loosened, & the nations echo round
Shaken to their roots: as do the mountains now. {SB}
{SD} Panthea
Look{;} how the gusty sea of mist is breaking
In crimson foam even at our feet--it rises
As Ocean at the inchantment of the moon
Round foodless men wrecked on some oozy isle {SB}
{SD} Asia
The fragments of the cloud are scattered up--
The wind which lifts them disentwines my hair--
Its' billows now sweep oer my eyes--my brain
Grows dizzy--<del>I</del> see «ins»st those«/ins» shapes within the mist{?} {SB}
{SD} Panthea
A countenance with beckoning smiles--there burns
An azure fire within its golden locks--
Another & another--hark they speak! {SB}
{SD} Song of Spirits
To the Deep, to the Deep
Down, Down!
Through the shade of Sleep
Through the cloudy strife
Of Death and of life
Through the viel & the bar
Of things which seem & are
Even to the steps of the remotest Throne
Down, Down! {SB}
While the sound, whirls around,
Down, Down!
As the fawn draws the hound
As the lightning the vapour
As a weak moth the taper
Death Despair, Love Sorrow
Time both, To-day to-morrow;
As steel obeys the Spirit of the stone
Down, Down {SB}
Through the grey void Abysm
Down, Down!
Where the air is no prism
And the moon & stars are not
And the cavern-crags wear not
The radiance of Heaven,
Nor the gloom to Earth given;
Where there is One pervading, One alone{,}
Down, Down! {SB}
In the depth of the Deep
Down, Down!
Like veil'd Lightning asleep,
Like that spark nursed in embers
The last look Love remembers,
Like a diamond which shines
On the dark wealth of mines
A spell is hidden, but from thee alone--
Down Down! {SB}
We have bound thee, we guide thee
Down Down!
With the bright form beside thee--
Resist not the weakness--
Such strength is in meekness--
«und»That the Eternal the Immortal«/und» /That the Eternal the Immortal
Must unloose thro life's portal
The snake-like Doom coiled underneath his throne
By that alone! {SB}
<SCENE 4> Scene 4 the Cave of Demogorgon Asia, Panthea,
{SD} Panthea
What veiled form sits on that ebon throne. {SB}
{SD} Asia
The veil has fallen! . . {SB} {HL}
{SD} Panthea
I see a mighty Darkness
Filling the seat of power{;} and rays of gloom
Dart round, as light from the meridian Sun
Ungazed upon & shapeless--. . neither limb
Nor form nor outline yet we feel it is
A living Spirit {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
{A}sk what thou wouldst know {SB}
{SD} Asia
What canst thou tell? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
All things thou darest demand {SB}
{SD} Asia
Who made the living world? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
God. {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
Who made all
That it contains--thought, passion, reason, will,
Imagination? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
God, Almighty God. {SB}
{SD} Asia
Who made that sense which when the winds of sp{r}ing
In rarest visitation, or the voice
Of one beloved heard in youth alone
Fills the faint eyes with falling tears, which dim
The radiant looks of unbewailing flowers
And leaves this peopled earth a solitude
When it returns no more {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
Merciful God {SB}
{SD} Asia
And who made terror, madness, crime, remorse
Which from the links of the great chain of things
To every thought within the mind of man
Sway & drag heavily--and each one reels
Under the load towards the pit of death;
Abandoned hope, & love that turns to hate
And Self-contempt, bitterer to drink than blood;
Pain whose unheeded & familiar speech
Is howling & keen shrieks, day after day,
And Hell, or the sharp fear of Hell? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
He reigns {SB}
{SD} Asia
Utter his name--a world pining in pain
Asks but his name; curses shall drag him down. {SB}
{SD} Demogorgon
He reigns {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
I feel, I know it--who? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
He reigns. {SB}
{SD} Asia
Who reigns? thier was the Heaven & Earth at first
And Light & Love{;--}then Saturn, from whose throne
Time fell, an envious shadow; such the state
Of the w«und»orl«/und»d's earth primal spirits beneath his sway
As the calm joy of flowers & living leaves
Before the wind or sun have withered them
And semivital worms; but he refused
<del>The spirit</del> birthrights of their being, knowledge & power,
The skill which wields the elements, the thought
Which pieerces this dim Universe like light,
Self-empire & the majesty of love{;}
For thirst of which they fainted; then Prometheus
Gave wisdom, which is strength, to Jupiter
And with this Law alone: let man be free,
Clothed him with the dominion of wide Heaven.
To know nor faith nor love nor law, to be
Omnipotent but friendless, is to reign;
And Jove now reigned; for on the race of man
First famine & then toil & then disease
Strife, wounds, & ghastly death unseen before
Fell, and the unseasonable seasons drove
With alternating shafts of frost & fire
Their shelterless pale tribes to mountain caves
And in their desart hearts fierce wants he sent
And mad disquietudes, & shadows idle
Of unreal good, which levied mutual war,
So ruining the lair wherein they raged.
Prometheus saw, & waked the legioned hopes
Which sleep within folded Elysian flowers,
Nepenthe, Moly, Amaranth, fadeless blooms;
That they might hide with thin & rainbow wings
The shape of death, and love he sent to bind
The disunited tendrils of that vine
Which bears the wine of life, the human heart;
And he tamed fire, which like some beast of {?chase}
Most terrible, but lovely, played beneath
The frown of man, & tortured to his will
Iron & gold, the slaves & signs of power;
And gems & poisons, & all subtlest forms
Hidden beneath the mountains & the waves
He gave man speech, & speech created thought
Which is the measure of the Universe
And Science struck the thrones of Earth & Heaven
Which shook but fell not; and the harmonious mind
Poured itself forth in all-prophetic song,
And music lifted up the listening spirit
Until it walked, exempt from mortal care,
Godlike, o'er the clear billows of sweet sound;
And human hands first mimicked & then mocked
With moulded limbs more lovely than its own
The human form, until till marble grew divine,
And mothers, gazing, drank the love men see
Reflected in their race--behold{,} & perish--
He told the hidden power of herbs & spings
And Disease drank & slept--Death grew like sleep,--
He taught the implicated orbits woven
Of the wide-wandering stars, & how the Sun
Changes his lair{s} {--}& by what secret spell
The pale moon is transformed, when her broad eye
Gazes not on the interlunar {S}ea;
He taught to rule, as life directs the limbs,
The tempest-winged chariots of the Ocean
And the Celt knew the Indian: Cities then
Were built, & thro their snowlike columns flowed
The warm winds, & the azure æther shone
And the blue sea & shadowy hills were seen . . .
Such the alleviations of his state
Prometheus gave to man--for which he hangs
Withering in destined pain--but who rains down
Evil, the immedicable plague, which while
Man looks on his creation like a God
And sees that it is glorious, drives him on
The wreck of his own will, the scorn of Earth,
The outcast, the abandoned, the alone?--
Not Jove, while yet his frown shook Heaven, aye when
His adversary from adamantine chains
Cursed him, he trembled like a slave: Declare
Who is his master? is he too a slave? {SB}
{SD} Demogorgon
All spirits are enslaved which serve things evil.
Thou knowest if Jupiter be such or no. {SB}
{SD} Asia
Whom calledst thou God? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
I spoke but as ye speak--
For Jove is the supreme of living things. {SB}
{SD} Asia
Who is the master of the slave? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
--If the Abysm
Could vomit forth its secrets:--but a voice
Is wanting, the deep truth is imageless;
For what would it avail to bid thee gaze
On the revolving world? what to bid speak
Fate, Time, Occasion, Chance & Change:--To these
All things are subject but eternal love. {SB}
{SD} Asia
So much I asked before, & my heart gave
The response thou hast given; & of such truths
Each to itself must be the oracle.--
One more demand . . . and do thou answer me
As my own soul would answer, did it know
That which I ask--Prometheus shall arise
Henceforth the Sun of this rejoicing world
When shall the destined hour arrive? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
Behold! {SB}
{SD} Asia
The rocks are cloven, & through the purple night
I see Cars drawn by rainbow-winged steeds
Which trample the dim winds{:} in each there stands
A wild-eyed charioteer, urging their flight{.}
Some look behind, as fiends pursued them there
And yet I see no shapes but the keen stars
Others with burning eyes lean forth, & drink
With eager lips the wind oftheir own speed
As if the thing they loved fled on before
And now--even now they clasped it; their bright hair
like a comets <del>Streams on the blast like meteors & they</del> & all
Sweep onward-- {SB} {HL}
{SD} Demogorgon
These are the immortal Hours
Of whom thou didst demand--one waits for thee {SB}
{SD} Asia
A {S}pirit with a dreadful countenance
Checks its dark chariot by the craggy gulph
Unlike thy brethren--ghastly charioteer
What art thou? whither wouldst thou bear me? speak {SB}
{SD} Spirit
I am the shadow of a destiny
More dread than is my aspect{--}ere yon planet
Has set, the Darkness which ascends with me
Shall wrap in lasting night Heaven's kingless throne {SB}
{SD} Asia
What meanest thou? {SB} {HL}
{SD} Panthea
The terrible shadow floats
Up from its throne, as may the lurid dust
Of earthquake-ruined cities oer the sea--
Lo! it ascends the Car . . . the coursers fly
Terrified; & watch its path among the stars
Blackening the night {SB} {HL}
{SD} Asia
Thus I am answered--strange! {SB}
{SD} Panthea
See, near the verge another chariot stays
An ivory shell inlaid with crimson fire
Which comes & goes within its sculptured rim
Of delicate strange tracery--the young Spirit
That guides it, has the dovelike eyes of hope.
How its soft smiles attract the soul!--as light
Lures winged insects thro the lampless air. {SB}
{SD} Spirit
My coursers are fed with the lightning
They drink of the whirlwind's stream
And when the red morning is brightning
They bathe in the fresh sunbeam;
They have strength for their swiftness I deem
Then ascend with me Daughters of Ocean {SB}
I desire--& their speed makes night kindle;
I fear--they outstrip the Typhoon;
Ere the cloud piled on Atlas can dwindle
We encircle the earth & the moon{;}
We shall rest from long labours ere noon{--}
Then ascend with me daughters of Ocean {SB}
<SCENE 5> Scene--The Car pauses within a cloud on the top of a snowy mountain
{SD} Spirit
On the brink of the night & the morning
My coursers are wont to respire,
But the Earth has just whispered a warning
That their flight must be swifter than fire
They shall drink the hot speed of desire! {SB}
{SD} Asia
Thou breathest on their nostrils--but my breath
Would give them swifter speed {SB} {HL}
{SD} Sp«und»iri«/und»t
Alas, it could not. {SB}
{SD} Panthea
O {s}pirit pause & tell whence is the light
Which fills this cloud--the sun is yet unrisen {SB}
{SD} Spirit
The sun will rise not until noon--Apollo
Is held in Heaven by wonder--and the light
Which fills this vapour, as the aerial hue
Of fountain-gazing roses fills the water
Flows from thy mighty sister {SB} {HL}
{SD} Panthea
Yes, I feel . . . {SB}
{SD} Asia
What is it with thee sister? thou art pale {SB}
{SD} Panthea
How thou art changed! I dare not look on thee
I feel, but see thee not. I scarce endure
The radiance of thy beauty. Some good change
Is working in the elements which suffer
Thy presence thus unveiled--the Nereids tell
That on the day when the clear hyaline
Was cloven at thy uprise, & thou didst stand
Within a veined shell, which floated on
Over the calm floor of the chrystal sea,
Among the Egean isles, & by the shores
Which bear thy name, love, like the atmosphere
Of the sun's fire filling the living world
Burst from thee, and illumined Earth & Heaven
And the deep ocean & the sunless caves
And all that dwell within them; till grief cast
Eclipse upon the soul from which it came:
Such art thou now, nor is it I alone
Thy sister thy companion, thine own chosen one
But the whole world which seeks thy sympathy.
Hearest thou not sounds i the air which speak the {l}ove
Of all articulate beings? feelest thou not
The inanimate winds enamoured of thee?--list Music {SB}
{SD} Asia
Thy words are sweeter than aught else but his
Whose echoes they are--yet all love is sweet
Given or returned; common as light is love
And its familiar voice wearies not ever
Like the wide Heaven, the all-sustaining air
It makes the reptile equal to the God . . .
They who inspire it most, are fortunate
As I am now{:} but those who feel it most
Are happier still, after long sufferings
As I shall soon become {SB} {HL}
{SD} <del>Panthea</del>
list, spirits speak{.} {SB}
{SD} Voice in the Air
Life of life! thy lips enkindle
With their love the breath between them
And thy smiles before they dwindle
Make the cold air fire; then screen them
In those looks where whoso gazes
Faints, entangled in their mazes {SB}
Child of Light! thy limbs are burning
Thro the vest which seems to hide them
As the radiant lines of morning
Through the clouds ere they divide them
And this atmosphere divinest
Shrouds thee whereso'er thou shinest {SB}
Fair are others;--none beholds thee,
But thy voice sounds low & tender
Like the fairest--for it folds thee
From the sight that liquid splendour
And all feel, yet see thee never
As I feel now, lost forever! {SB}
Lamp of Earth! where'er thou movest
Its dim shapes are clad with brightness
And the souls of whom {those} thou lovest
Walk upon the winds with lightness
Till they fail, as I am failing,
. .Dizzy, lost . . . yet unbewailing {SB}
{SD} Asia
My soul is an enchanted Boat
Which, like a sleeping swan, doth float
Upon the silver waves of thy sweet singing,
And thine doth like an Angel sit
Beside the helm conducting it
Whilst all the winds with melody are ringing
It seems to float ever--forever--
Upon that many winding River
Between{s} mountains, woods, abysses,
A Paradise of wildernesses,
Till like one in slumber bound
Borne to the Ocean, I float, down, around,
Into a Sea profound, of ever-spreading sound {SB}
Meanwhile thy Spirit lifts its pinions
In Music's most serene dominions
Catching the winds that fan that happy Heaven
And we sail on, away, afar,
Without a course--without a star--
But by the instinct of sweet Music driven
Till, through Elysian garden islets,
By thee{,} most beautiful of pilots,
Where never mortal pinnace glided
The boat of my desire is guided--
Realms where the air we breathe is Love
Which in the winds & on the waves doth move{,}
night Harmonizing this Earth with what we feel above {SB}
We have past Age's icy caves,
And Manhood's dark & tossing waves
And Youth's smooth ocean, smiling to betray;
Beyond the glassy gulphs we flee
Of shadow-peopled infancy,
Thro death & birth, to a diviner day{;}
A Paradise of vaulted bowers
Lit by down ward-gazing flowers
And watery paths that wind between
{?Eu} Wildernesses calm & green
Peopled by shapes too bright to see
And rest, having beheld; somewhat like thee
Which walk upon the sea & chaunt melodiously
